I'm gonna talk today about learning to code and I think that as Michael said this is this is a some of the stuff that
I do but it's some of the stuff that I think is most important today in a lot of the things happening in the world so
I want to give give my attention to this topic and try to give you a sense of how I'm thinking about learning to code in
society today and how people in the world are thinking about it too and some of the tensions between my perspectives
and and others so a bit about myself to to go deeper I've been a professor at
the University of Washington in Seattle for about 10 years now tenured and I did my PhD at Carnegie Mellon at the HCI
Institute and for context I was part of the third cohort there and so figuring out what a PhD 8th and HCI even meant at
the time was still a nun undetermined question and so it was a lot of fun to be part of that formative first couple
of classes at CMU and then I have a very interdisciplinary background I studied computer science and psychology as an
undergraduate I took a lot of design courses when I was a PhD student and I've continued to try to pick up new
disciplines and new backgrounds and if lately been reading a lot about learning science as part of that and so I tend to
think of myself as somebody who really is a breath wise scholar and not not necessarily going deep into a discipline
but I do that from the perspective of thinking about what code is so here's
the perspective that I start with in my work I think as an HCI researcher of code as the most powerful interface that
we've ever invented but it's also the least usable interface that we've ever invented it's the hardest thing to use to create
to express right it's a lot easier to go open up some Adobe product and do some graphic design than it is to go write
some software to do what you want and I kind of sort of think from a justice perspective that everybody that wants to
be able to harness this power should be able to harness it it's something that we should allow people to do by lowering
barriers whenever possible but there really are immense barriers to doing this and so when I was a PhD student and
for the Civil years of my faculty career I spent a lot of time trying to lower these barriers by creating new developer tools
and other kinds of technologies that would make it easier to express easier to debug easier to test verify all of
these activities and I thought that that was sort of the most powerful way for me to spend my time was creating
technologies that would would lower barriers what happened was I took a small leave and started a company and
ended up actually engineering and and managing a lot of Engineers and I realized something that was sort of
evident every day and that's that skills are just more powerful than tools what human beings can do and what kinds of
insights they have about how to solve problems there are the things that drive our use of tools it's not the other way
around right so the kinds of things I saw tools were amplifying people's abilities if they knew what they were
doing they could harness tools to do amazing things if my engineers had no idea what they were doing tools just
derailed them they ended up somewhere that was unproductive and if we want people to have skills
skills come from learning learning comes from teaching and as a result as a manager of engineers I spend most of my
time teaching skills that was my primary job as a chief technology officer and that was a really pivotal ID idea for me
I mean sort of rethinking my own scholarship because it meant that tools were not really the objective or the
powerful agent of change in the work that I was doing but rather skills and and all of the problem-solving behind it
that's what I actually needed to develop if I wanted to lower barriers to harnessing that power of code so at the
exact same time that I was having this realization the world also decided that this was a skill everybody should have
right so all of the things that happen on the left and are happening now code org for example reaching its 500 million
learner milestone for the types of learning that happens in hour of code the President or former presidents
saying everybody should learn this or everybody that once too should learn this these are really powerful societal changes and they're not just in the
United States they're all over the world and then most recently on the right we have a fairly significant investment by
industry saying this is something that we want people to have access to as well so while I was realizing that this was
important to me as a scholar the world was deciding this was important sort of economically and from
a justice perspective and so this was really the right time for me to to make that pivot and think about these problems and so the first question that
I asked myself was is any of this working what do we know about whether
learning is happening and we have some evidence not great so feel free to pick it apart as much as you want but this is
this is the sort of converging ideas that we have around the evidence here's some evidence from code.org itself about
77% of the people who've done interactions with its code studio environment complete somewhere on the
order of zero to two puzzles and these are very very simple puzzles so if learning is happening not much is
happening right there's not a lot of engagement here and not a lot of activity if you look at AP Computer
Science in high schools in the United States there's record enrollment in AP CS and its companion ApS principles but
most don't take the exam and about 60% of who who do fail the exam meaning they
get a score of a1 or a2 and the failure rates are even higher for underrepresented minorities so there's
some more data that whatever we're doing in these high school classes kind of isn't working and the failure rates are much lower than other AP subjects so
that's high school if we look at college which is where a lot of the research has been and I'll talk about that shortly most undergrads if you really go to
systematically measure what students after a year of CS courses can do they can't do much they can't predict the
outcome of a simple program they can't really solve simple programming problems the knowledge they have is very very
brittle and the reason that we often don't notice this is because we only pay attention to the students that finish
right there's all of this dropout an attrition there's the students that get an A in the class but because our assessments aren't very valid or robust
we don't see that they're failing or that their knowledge is brittle so there's this sort of hidden masked
problem in the undergraduate setting that we don't often think about or talk about and then finally when you look at
coding boot camps for sure there's new phenomena from the past few years there were 23,000 adults last year that
enrolled in these about a quarter of those reported their dropout rates and the dropout rates range from 10 to 50
percent and most of them are on the higher end and so when you look at a lot of the experiences that students are having
here they're finding that they don't believe they can learn this material they're not getting feedback that they can so they leave so these are all of
the settings in which this learning is happening most of them were seeing the same things it's hard material to learn and teachers don't really know how to
teach it the last stat here that's sort of the most concerning is that there have been some recent surveys around how
software companies think about the skills that graduates have and about two-thirds of them say that entry-level
developers they'll hire them you know because they can't they don't have any other options but they generally don't
have the basic programming knowledge that they need to be productive in a company and not even just from a sort of
soft skills software engineering perspective but even just basic understandings of how programming languages work how software is
architected and so on there's a gap there so I did some more reading on why
all of this failure might be happening I read all of the seminal literature and learning science and education and I
read 30 years of computing education research to try to understand what these papers have to say about this and these
are some of the venues where that's published and if you distill it all down I think most people in the field that
publish this would agree that there are six problems here probably more but the six major ones one people really do find
computing very boring very solitary and very unwelcoming in most of the settings in which it's taught to people struggle
to learn their first programming language and if they don't get past that they don't really move any further past that people struggle to solve
programming problems they don't have a process for solving problems and nobody really teaches the process teachers
struggle to teach these things and perhaps the most surprising is that number five most teachers one day
struggle to teach them they don't blame themselves they blame learners they say that learners must be broken in some way
there must be some people that know how to code and some people that don't so let's just focus on the ones that are succeeding and then finally because of
all of these things most learners lose confidence and give up and this happens over and over again in all of these
different settings in which people are trying to learn and these are big nasty
gnarly problems they happen probably on this campus they certainly happen on our campus at the University of
Washington they happen in the 25 coding boot camps all around the Puget Sound that we've that we've looked at and now
they're gonna happen in high schools middle schools and K through K through five settings right so this is not just
a problem of higher ed anymore it's a problem in this country for all forms of education and in the rest of the world
so in reducing this down and trying to focus some of my goals have been trying
to look at these problems of learning programming languages and programming process I think there are challenging
things are in the socio-cultural aspects of learning that that I'm not well equipped to answer and I think that we

this content so I want to talk about that and the rest of this talk and try to figure out why are they hard and what

under the program I'm so difficult I've done a lot of ways to look at this
problem one of them is just by engaging deeply with people who are learning this is a group of of students that I taught
a couple of summers ago through our Upward Bound program at the University of Washington so these are all first-generation college students who
had some curiosity about about programming and learning to code and I just engage with them deeply and and
mentored a lot of them and over the past couple of summers worked with about 70 of them most of them in Seattle are
refugees from other countries that have just arrived in Seattle and some of them are our locals but most of them are
refugees and some of the things that we found this is just highlights many teens
locked feedback or support about their learning from teachers or from anybody else so here's a quote he doesn't spend
much time with me to be able to understand my problem in the class or help me on it throughout the AP class I'd cry myself to sleep in silence
without letting my older brother know my sister all right so this brother was the one that encouraged him to take the class in
the first place and then he provided no support so that's an experience right some teens actually had productive
informal mentoring relationships they these mentors provided encouragement and instruction and guidance and feedback
and all of that was associated with higher interest in learning to code and
this was independent of gender or socioeconomic status so there was this really interesting relationship between just having one person that encouraged
your learning to keep somebody engaged over time and they really sought
teachers and mentors who wouldn't judge them for their failures who would inspire them to learn who had the
expertise to actually guide them towards developing new skills and these are
really sort of common things amongst most kinds of learning and education I think we often just forget them when we
talk about computing another setting that we've looked at is boot camps and so one of my students Kyle fair did an
interview study with recent graduates or dropouts of 26 different coding boot
camps in the Puget Sound region and he found a couple of interesting things about their experiences their son son
boot camps were very inclusive and encouraging very intentionally so but others were not and they offered no
instruction or feedback so here's a quote so they're trying to get you into this mentality if you have to read all
the documentation they sit in the background so let students read it and what annoys me is that I paid a lot of
money so that somebody could teach it to me they weren't here to just read API Docs right they were here to help
somebody instruct them through other boot camps offered some unwelcoming
culture that we might all be familiar with in other settings especially for learners without prior knowledge here's
a quote it was divided the class those with experience I think they were looking down at those of us without experience because maybe there were
certain things we were supposed to know that we didn't right so these are other socio-cultural factors and kind of
shaping whether somebody felt included and encouraged we've also looked at
things less empirically and more analytically we took a look at 30 coding tutorials and this is a student I've
worked with a doctoral student who didn't know how to code but wanted to learn so we had her go and use the 30 most
popular coding tutorials on the web to see how much she could learn and then analyze it from a learning perspective
so we kind of looked at for learning science principles these tutorials should connect instruction to prior
knowledge organize declarative knowledge direct facts about programming languages and other things offer personalized
feedback on practice and foster some self regulated learning in the problem-solving that it was asking
people to do while they were writing code so the student ADA she completed all of these tutorials analyzed every
element of her experience against all four of these and found that most of these tutorials don't do any of these
things right and not surprisingly the small number of studies that we've looked at for the learning outcomes of
these tutorials show that most mostly no learning happens you can get this great experience of having been exposed to
coding but mostly people can't do anything after they've finished this so
synthesizing this why is it so difficult few of these contexts actually teach
programming there are many opportunities to read and write code in all of these settings right you get exposed to it you
encounter it but learners really receive very little feedback on whether they're reading it correctly or they're writing
it correctly it's almost as if we expect learners just by exposure to be able to
infer everything they need to know about how to write programs and and it shouldn't be surprising that since they
received no instruction on it that they don't you don't actually make that inference so the first half of things I
want to present around interventions for this is about reading and I want to talk about what reading code is about and try
to theorize about that and talk about some of our efforts to teach it and then we'll do writing and then I'll wrap up
so here's why most people think understanding programs is hard and these
are sort of the fears that have existed for several decades a lot of people think that we just have the wrong programming language if we redesign
languages then reading will be easier and that's the solution to all of our problems others have talked about having
the wrong environment the wrong tools if we redesign those maybe everything will be easier to scarily some people still
believe in biology and biological explanation they believe that there's some people that have a geek gene that allows them
to read code effectively and other people don't have that gene and we just have to decide who has that gene by
making really hard midterms and final exams and we'll figure it out right there's no evidence for any of
these theories so I'm not saying they're wrong but we certainly don't know that they're right and so really where I'm
starting from is saying that the theories that we're just teaching it wrong right that's what's made these
things hard we need to find better ways of explaining how to read programs and so here's a definition that I'll propose
sort of theoretically I'll claim that knowing a programming language means two things being able to reliably and
accurately predict some arbitrary program's operational semantics what will it do
what will the program do without the aid of some other environment to actually execute the program
that's what knowing how to read a program means and then secondarily you have to know how all of those semantics
map onto syntax right because that's the notation that we use for expressing semantics it's a pretty basic definition
of that knowledge but it's tied to programming languages in a way that really other theories haven't been and
note that I'm sort of ignoring all of the other things like design patterns and architectures and tools there's a lot of other stuff you have to know to
write programs I'm just talking about reading them right now so here's an
example of what it means to know an if statement in JavaScript you have to know that first this condition is evaluated
second if it's true then the things in the first pair of curly braces happen
and if it's not true then the second thing happens and there's this other
critical knowledge that if the else branch is true cuz the expression is false then the then branch doesn't
execute which is a thing that a lot of beginners don't understand they think that it's just going to be sequential
because that's how well other reading works right so understanding those semantics is really key knowing a whole
language like all of JavaScript means knowing all of the semantics so in JavaScript for example there's about 90
ish non terminals in the grammar that map onto all of these semantic nuances knowing the whole semantics of
JavaScript means understanding all of those non terminals and their semantics and yet most intra program
classes most tutorials most coding boot camps and never teach any of these things in fact I looked at our recent version
of our CS one course at u-dub the first homework assignment is to write a Java program that has function declarations
function calls string literal string concatenation and a semantics of all of those things are never taught somehow
students are just supposed to magically infer how all of those things work right through the process of writing a program
we've looked at lots of ways in the community of teaching these things I
think it should be obvious that teaching people's semantics through formal notations like this probably doesn't
work right it doesn't teach syntax it requires learning another notation to learn a notation explaining semantics
via natural language doesn't work so well because that's ambiguous and there's a weak mapping to syntax you can
have people write programs and hope that they will somehow infer semantics through a process of debugging that doesn't work so well nobody ever infers
the semantics you might even have people step through a program's execution the challenge there is that this is always
at the granularity of a line of code you have to somehow be able to see everything that happens inside of a complex expression all at once right and
again people will not will not infer semantics at that level of granularity so how should we teach semantics that's
the big question here and the approach that I'm that I'm gonna take here is teaching a notional machine some
representation of how the program operates and executes and so we'll show each step of the semantics and the
explicit effects of that part of the program on State on a program counter on
a call stack on memory and then map all of the semantics in those side effects to syntax so that learners create an
association between the syntax they're seeing in the notation and the side effects that that program is having and
its behavior so there's three ways that we've tried doing this I'm gonna give you a tour through them just so you can
see different ways that this basic pedagogy manifests the first one is Gidget and here the idea is take this
cute little robot that has been dented and is broken who cannot debug its programs and it needs your help and
frame coding as a collaboration between the learner and this robot and give learner a sequence of debugging puzzles
in which they counter the semantics of the programming language by seeing a broken program and seeing how those semantics play out in
its behavior and then the goal is to guide learners attention towards contextualized instruction about the
programming languages semantics so that they can map those on to syntax and build that knowledge so here's here's
how it plays out there's a splash screen and they get to learn a little bit about the environment and see the story behind
Gidget being broken and not being able to solve its problems and then there's a variety of panels here around the code
on the left and the runtime state on the right and then there's a test case in
the bottom left that verifies whether the puzzles been solved by just having a certain output and state be possible and
then all of this instruction happens down here and get its thought bubble and so over the course of 37 levels in this
game it teaches the 12 major semantics of the programming language and includes lots of formative assessments to verify
that somebody understands them so that's the overarching curriculum so we'll jump ahead to level 20 this is where they
learn functions and function calls and here what happens is we have a lot of embedded instruction so there's
explanations about what functions are what they're used for why they're valuable so there's a bit of
semantics explanation there digit here is explaining the syntax and how that
maps on to the semantics through this instruction as they execute the program
step by step it's like running through with a breakpoint debugger but at the token level instead of the line level
and seeing every single one of those pieces of side-effect from the program executing and that green line underlines
the part of the semantics that's being explained so gadgets job as they step through it is to say what happened as a
result of that part of the program executing building up that association between syntax and semantics and then in
this case we're trying to expose them to function calls and how to call functions and so Gidget points out where the
functions are sort of listed this is like an API documentation right here and this gate has this open gate function
that the program is trying to call you might already notice on the top there that it's calling open fence instead of
open gate so it's a pretty simple defect in the program we just want a guide to learn his attention to that and so the learners
going to step through and see that it couldn't find a function called open fence and then they supposed to see this
association that is called open gate and once they've recognized that there's
this notion of name resolution that the names have to match for the functions to be called then they can go repair that
defect step through their program and see it work correctly so the general theme here is that learners are
encountering semantics right it's actually not as aggressive as maybe our theory would recommend it's just showing
the semantics to them and hoping that they understand this Association but what you found is that actually works
reasonably well there we did for online controlled experiments about a thousand
adult learners across all of these studies we found that learning is twice as fast as in the code Academy tutorial
for python and it's about twice as much for open-ended creative exploration there are levels that involve
assessments where we're asking learners to predict the output of programs and including those assessments increases
learning efficiency by about double we also found interesting design factors like how do we get learners to pay
attention to that instruction to engage its thought-bubble it turns out by just giving the robot eyes and having it use
personal pronouns like I and you and we try to try to establish that collaborative relationship we redirected
their attention towards that instruction rather than to other parts of the interface and so trying to do that in an
online environment was key I mean all of this has really rapid effects on attitudes as well when you have adults
for example play this for 20 minutes they their opinions about whether learning to code is easy shift from being it's the hardest thing I could
never learn it - that was fun give me more right how do I learn more so it's a
very rapid shift in attitude this has had some impact so 20,000 people have
played the game so far this directly informed the design of code or code studio and a lot of the ways that they
provide instruction and it also directly informed the design of Apple's Swift playgrounds which is a similar
environment for learning the Swift programming language the second strategy
was much more explicit rather than trying to let learners encounter the semantics of a programming language this
strategy is around explicitly teaching those semantics and guiding somebody through that mapping of syntax to
semantics so here the idea was create this an interactive textbook where learners walk through step by step the
program's execution and along the way we explain what's happening each step and then ask learners to predict for certain
parts of the program what will happen next and the idea here is to sort of use a causal inference model where somebody sees this mapping between this syntax
executing with this side-effect and then be able to build up that knowledge by having somebody predict what that
side-effect would be so I'll show you an example of that and we did this for JavaScript so this is the entire
JavaScript semantics each chapter covers some of the semantics in JavaScript and
it takes about three hours to go through this and so the goal here is teach JavaScript in three hours and have that
knowledge be more robust than something you might learn in a 10-week course or a 15-week course so it's basically divided
into three sections there's a lesson on the left that explains why in the world would you want to understand this part
of the programming language at all what is it for the middle shows the program and its syntax and that links syntax to
semantics and then the right on-state shows the program's runtime state but also explains the side effects of each
instruction on that state so here's how it plays out here's an if statement it's
describing what if statements are for and giving some example of the syntax
and then saying that we're gonna step through an if statement and see how it executes this next button is moving
through an execution trace of this program history right so you can see on the top those little bubbles popping up
and down that's each individual step of this program's execution recorded and and captures so that we can actually
insert instruction into certain parts of the programs execution history and then
as they step through it the state is saying things like this is an if statement it's used to perform some
steps conditionally the first step of in this statement is to evaluate its condition to see whether the step should be performed and so they're reading and
side effects as they go along through this program's execution and then they can also go reverse
because we have a trace of the program's execution history so if they miss something or need to see an explanation
again they can just step backwards go back and see that instruction again and then go forward so it's a completely
linear way of stepping through a program and understanding how it executes and
then finally it ties it back in the lesson explains the side effect of the semantics and then gives more examples
as they as they go forward then the last thing I said that they're asked to
predict what will happen so here's an example of somebody saying well what did the zero greater than ten part of this
example do what will end up on the stack over here this should be true or false they look like true which was wrong and
it gave an explanation and they realized why it was wrong and then chose false and that was the resulting of that
operation right so very granular explanation of exactly everything that's happening as the program executes so
what was the effect of this part of this was actually trying to build this in the first place we had to completely react
detect the language stuck we had to build a parser that would maintain provenance of the origins of all of the
tokens and parts of the grammar so that we could link that to runtime state we
had to facilitate reversibility and embedded instruction in an execution trace so if anybody knows anything about
how you build a compiler this is a completely different architecture for building a compiler to make this instruction possible right we also had
to redesign the language grammar to facilitate more granular explanations of parts of the programming language as
well and the effect of it was when we ran a four-hour controlled experiment to have somebody have students go through
this we had about 40 cs1 students who hadn't ever learned the programming language before and we
measured learning with this new validated assessment of cs1 outcomes the tutor led to 60% higher scores on this
test compared to the code Academy JavaScript tutorial and did that in
about half the time as well so very rapid learning in just a couple of hours for all of the JavaScript language
semantics the most exciting thing is that we in a small sample we almost also
saw an increase in their midterm scores that train for to Java which is what our cs1 course
is taught in so that was explicit instruction of semantics this last one
I'll talk about is reminding the learner to follow the semantics reminding that the semantics exist and having them have
a strategy around using them so my newest student Benjy che he started from
this premise that when learners have really brittle knowledge of semantics their strategy is often to just guess
what the semantics are and then they use that to reason about how the program will execute so he wanted to give them
an explicit strategy for reading programs that prompted them to use their knowledge of the semantics in their
reading of the code and that should outperform guessing so the strategy was really simple this is the strategy it
was understand what you're being asked to do find where the program begins executing execute each line according to
the rules of Java and then there's this sub strategy from the syntax figure out the rule follow the rules map the
side-effects of the rules and then find the code for the next part that will execute it's a really basic top level
strategy for how to read a program and this is the result so they end up with
this program on a piece of paper lots of annotations that follow that strategy and then the effect of this as
predicted is pretty powerful so in just 15 minutes of practice of this strategy the 12 students who learned the strategy
were more systematic than the 12 who didn't they had 15% higher performance on some tracing problems we gave them in
the lab almost a great point higher on the midterm that they took about four weeks later after this experiment and in
the experimental condition none of the students failed the midterm where as 25% of the control group participants did so
this really simple strategy of just 15 minutes of practice sort of transformed their ability to read programs so this
synthesis here is when it comes to reading code and understanding what programs do requiring learners to
directly observe the operational semantics of a programming language and map them onto syntax can really promote
much better learning outcomes than we can't otherwise now I'm not assuming that they're going to infer these things on their own
but explicitly instructing on them it's very powerful this last half of this
last part of the talk is going to be about writing problems we haven't made as much progress on this I think it's a harder problem but I want to talk about
a theory that we have an idea for how to how to teach this more effectively and so when we think about program writing
there's actually little work trying to figure out what does it mean to know how to write programs anyway what is that
skill what is what does that school composed of most work kind of talks about the differences between experts
and novices shows that novices are sort of unsystematic and that they're speculative and this is mostly
ineffective there are few papers that show that the most effective developers are better self regulators that they
regulate their problem-solving and and that is related to more higher productivity so here's what this concept
means it's basically a set of skills that you probably all recognize in
yourselves as successful people explicit planning skills explicit monitoring of
your process explicit monitoring of what you understand and what you don't understand reflection on your cognition
right metacognition self explanation of the decisions you make why did you decide this why did you not all of these
executive functions around better problem solving or generally correlated with lots of better learning outcomes
and better problem solving in lots of disciplines the hypothesis is that this is true in programming as well and in
fact when we look at sort of in practice one of the studies that we've done for my former students Paul Lee he
interviewed about 59 Microsoft senior developers and almost 2000 in a survey
and he found that when developers reported what made somebody a great engineer self-regulating self-regulation
skills where one of the top three attributes and what makes somebody a great engineer so that skill seems to be
an intrinsic part of writing code writing great software so my student
Dustin I took this work and started theorizing about how is self-regulation related to writing software in what way
does it actually help somebody write code so he talked about programming is involving sort of six
core activities interpreting the problem they're solving searching for similar
problems that they might solve it searching for solutions to those problems evaluating those solutions
implementing them and then evaluating the implementation and note that writing code is is just this one bullet here
right everything else here is actually about planning everything else here is about trying to reflect on decisions
that she's made and so his theory was that programming what it really requires is a whole big repository of a whole
bunch of patterns of solutions to problems and understanding of about the mapping between problems and solutions
and then the key thing is that self-regulation skills actually link all of these activities they help you decide
when to switch from one to the next it help you decide when it's time to evaluate when it's time to try rewriting
something and so on and developing those skills is actually the challenging part of writing code so the first thing he
set out to do was find out if this was was true and so he looked at sort of a
cognitive interview a think aloud study with 37 novices that were in a couple of interosseous courses and had them write
solutions to some programming problems and he found that most novices get engaged in some degree of
self-regulation but most of it was infrequent or shallow or superficial in
some way they weren't very good at it yet but when we looked at those who did it well they were actually much more
highly correlated with fewer errors in the programs that they wrote only when they had sufficient prior knowledge
right if they if they had mastered the concepts in what we were testing and what problems they were solving those
self-regulation skills were really powerful if they didn't have that knowledge it didn't matter how good they were self-regulating they still failed
so that was pretty consistent with the theory that we had we had developed so the big question is here can we actually
teach these self-regulation skills because if we can then everybody can be a better developer they can write
programs more effectively so what we tried to do is we set up a two-week summer camp with 48 high schoolers none
of them had at Overtoun any code before we spent the first week teaching them HTML CSS JavaScript and react and for
those who don't know what react is it's not the easiest thing to learn it's a pretty difficult a distraction
to wrap your mind around and so this was a strong test right we were trying to figure out how far can we get somebody
with no knowledge of programming to go in two weeks so the treatment group
received a couple of things they learned about Dustin eyes theory of programming so they had explicit knowledge of how we
believed programming worked and what was hard about it and then critically they received this intervention and the
intervention was anytime one of the high schoolers wanted help before we would
offer them help we would ask them to say what activity are they doing what was
their strategy for performing that activity and was their strategy working and the purpose of that was to try to
foster these self-regulating skills to help them reflect on their planning on their comprehension on their strategies
and so on and so I mean the control group we would just help them immediately like you would a TA in a
class right so inserting this self-regulating prompting in in this protocol was the key part of developing
this this skill so here's the outcome along four measures
there was great success so the experimental group participants who got that prompting accomplished more in that
last week of class so they completed not only more of the requirements that we had for the class but they also defined
the requirements of their own and completed more of those their self-efficacy was higher significantly
over the last course of that week these are longitudinal results on the bottom
left the green bars there are all of the self defined requirements that students performed and so they came up with more
of their own requirements and if and finished them then the control group did and then lastly here I thought this was
one of the most powerful things is that this trend here of of growth mindset it
actually declined in the control group over time which is something that others have reported in higher ed settings as
well that's really scary the idea that learning to code in a certain way would make you believe that you can't learn
things anymore that's a scary outcome of a class we prevented that erosion through these self-regulation prompting
interventions so these are these are really exciting results that means not only can we teach some of these skills
in a class and it can result in very short time better outcomes from learning perspective but that we can
actually help preserve some of these beliefs about learning future things that's really exciting so when we talk
about writing programs really the lesson here is the teaching programming
self-regulation skills really promotes important things like independence and increased productivity and higher self
